task.title: Downgrade a Failed Upgrade
task.shortdesc: If your upgrade fails, this topic describes how to downgrade your cloud to an earlier release.

context.p: The upgrade process creates a backup to /var/lib/eucalyptus/upgrade/eucalyptus.backup.TIMESTAMP. For example:
If the upgrade fails and needs to be reverted to your earlier version, you can find your preserved data in this directory.
If the upgrade fails, all changes to the database and configuration files will be rolled back. You can retry the upgrade by following the upgrade instructions in the sections, and .

If you do not want to continue with the upgrade after a failure, you can downgrade your installation back to the previous version. Please note that downgrade instructions are different, depending on whether your services are co-located or each hosted on their own machine. You will need to perform the downgrade for all services running on a single machine at the same time.

The /var/lib/eucalyptus/db and /var/lib/eucalyptus/keys directories should not be affected by the upgrade. If they have been removed subsequent to the upgrade, you must restore the contents of these directories from your backups before downgrading.
To downgrade from a failed upgrade, perform the tasks listed in the following sections.

taskbody.context: If you have installed RHEL 7 and re-installed , then the only way to downgrade to is to perform a clean install of RHEL 6 (wiping out RHEL 7), then install following the Installation Guide (not the guide), then restore your cloud state following the "Recover Cloud Data" section of the Administration Guide, using the cloud data you backed up before installing RHEL 7. If you want to apply the current RHEL7 state to your downgraded install, such as object storage data, follow the section on RHEL 7 before installing RHEL 6.
